13.05.text:
>> Cathy Willis Spraetz

17.40.text:

22.05.text:

rooted in human services.

26.00.text:
Spraetz headed nonprofits
focused on people

28.38.text:

34.67.text:

41.14.text:

46.75.text:
and about chimp art
and surprise births.

Here's our conversation
with Cathy Willis Spraetz.

1367.62.text:
Some, in her descriptions, are
absolutely horrendous in terms

1371.17.text:
of the size of the
space and the fact

1373.39.text:
that these very social
primates are isolated.

1378.40.text:
And, as you're seeing
in Chimp Haven,

1383.11.text:
Well, and you know I think it's
tough because when an animal is

1387.25.text:
in a research protocol very
often they're singly housed

1395.53.text:
in the environment really
changes the landscape.

1399.30.text:
But it is a very sad
existence for a chimpanzee

1406.43.text:
They live in very large
social groups in the wild.

1409.96.text:
Sometimes as many as 100
chimpanzees in a group.

1413.22.text:
So it's really gratifying
to us to get those chimps

1418.60.text:
at Chimp Haven in to
large social groups.

1420.59.text:
>> Well, interestingly, your
favorite chimpanzee Henry

1423.30.text:
who lived 15 years in a dark,
dank garage in his own filth,

1429.83.text:
came out and he wasn't well
socialized, but according

1433.62.text:
to Chimp Haven he's now
really the alpha male.

1436.85.text: >> So he's come a long way.

1438.93.text:
Now he probably wouldn't be the
alpha male in a different group,

1443.03.text:
but in this particular
group he is.

1444.92.text:
And they let him do that, you
know, without any problem.

1449.44.text:
When Henry first came he didn't
know how to be submissive,

1454.01.text:
and that's something
they learn from birth.

1456.58.text:
They learn the pecking
order and the hierarchy.

1459.52.text:
And there's a very
complicated hierarchy

1464.62.text:
And it changes, particularly
if there are more

1469.49.text:
And they're always vying and
jockeying for that position.

1472.40.text:
So to see Henry go from
being totally inappropriate

1477.92.text:
in a social setting, as far
as chimps are concerned,

1481.01.text:
to becoming the alpha male
is really quite a testimony

1487.70.text:
how smart they are and
how much they can learn.

1489.80.text:
>> You know, you're not open
to the public like a zoo,

1492.16.text: but you do engage the public

1493.70.text:
and education is an
important part of what you do.

1496.13.text:
What do you want
Americans most to know

1498.64.text:
about the chimpanzees
you're caring for?

1501.10.text:
>> Well, I think it's
really important for people

1504.90.text: Captive chimps live a long time.

1507.09.text:
They -- You know, we have --
Our oldest chimpanzee is 61.

1510.72.text:
And she shows no signs of
going anywhere any time soon.

1514.81.text:
And so they can live, you
know, well in to their 60s.

1519.22.text:
And it's really important
I think for people to know

1521.96.text:
that they did contribute
a lot to science.

1528.72.text:
And they -- You know, we always
say, "Oh, they gave so much,"

1533.41.text:
but we have to remember
they gave that unwillingly.

1538.58.text: I really do think we owe them.

1542.18.text:
for them is the very
best that we can do.

1544.83.text:
Thank you so much
Cathy Willis Spraetz.

1547.63.text:
It was a great pleasure
to be here.

1549.56.text:
>> I hope you enjoyed
our conversation

where you'll also find more

We hope you'll join us
for our next conversation

1640.66.text:
>> It is a very sad
existence for a chimpanzee

1647.20.text:
They live in very large
social groups in the wild.

1650.71.text:
